children: The specialty of hospital medicine has established itself as an important leader in key domains critical to hospital functioning. In addition to expertise in the management of inpatient medical issues, a hospitalist's core competencies, as defined by the Society of Hospital Medicine, include expertise in interdisciplinary communication and team-based care, perioperative and consultative medicine, prevention of health care–associated conditions, transitions of care, and patient safety.

The importance of quality communication among providers during a patient's hospitalization and care transitions has never been more evident. These periods typically involve numerous clinicians and providers when patients are vulnerable and the risk for medical errors is high. To minimize errors and potential complications, excellence in intra- and interprofessional communication and strong team leadership are expected competencies of all hospitalists.

Lines of communication for which an inpatient physician is responsible include communication with patients and families, specialty consultants, other hospitalists during handoffs, staff in other disciplines (therapists, social workers, pharmacists, nurses, case managers), primary care providers, and staff at skilled nursing and rehabilitation facilities. The use of specific communication tools and techniques may improve outcomes and reduce errors

Multidisciplinary team–based care delivery is a key strategy to improve care quality, patient safety, and overall outcomes. Critical elements of success in multidisciplinary teams include effective communication, mutual respect, clear roles and responsibilities, and alignment of goals. As a team leader, the hospitalist must monitor and bring together different parts of the care plan, incorporate input from multiple team members from different disciplines, provide feedback and mediate when conflict exists, ensure an environment of shared responsibility and respect, and appropriately delegate tasks. Regular team meetings with and without patients and families help ensure uniformity in treatment plans and care coordination and serve to update providers on all aspects of patient care and progress. These meetings often occur in the setting of changes in a patient's clinical course or in preparation for care transitions.

During complicated hospital stays with involvement of multiple specialty clinicians, hospitalists must also assess, prioritize, and implement recommendations by specialists and other consulting services in a timely fashion, if within the goals of care. Hospitalists are instrumental in synthesizing information and clearly communicating care plans to other providers, clinicians, patients, and families. Meticulous coordination of information among services and specialties improves consistency of messaging to patients and reduces fragmentation of care that can result in omissions, duplications, or discrepancies of care.

The frequent hand-offs between clinical teams inherent to hospital medicine require specific attention on the part of the hospitalist to prevent errors. Two thirds of sentinel events in the hospital occur in the setting of inadequate handoffs. Handoffs are defined as the transfer and acceptance of responsibility of patient care between clinicians through effective communication. Handoffs are high-frequency events in the hospital and can be difficult to do well. Strategies aimed at standardizing and improving handoffs, such as I-PASS (Illness severity, Patient summary, Action list, Situation awareness and contingency planning, Synthesis), provide a framework for the transfer of important information and promote consistency of practice (see

The potential for medical errors is particularly high at the time of hospital discharge, underscoring the importance of accurate information transfer between sites of care. When certain parts of care plans, including follow-up testing and treatment, are appropriate to be deferred until after discharge, the hospitalist is responsible for the handoff of this information to the appropriate accepting provider, typically the primary care team. Hospitalists most commonly communicate with primary care teams through the discharge summary, but a hospitalist may also directly contact primary care providers at the time of discharge. Key information that should be relayed at the time of discharge includes the reason for admission; diagnoses; hospital course; laboratory and imaging results; discharge medication list; pending tests; and postdischarge plan of care, including follow-up appointments.

Hospitalists are frequently asked to consult on the care of surgical, psychiatric, and nonmedical patients. This traditional medical consultation model addresses specific questions on medical management. The consultant's responsibilities are to confirm the question being asked, evaluate the patient, and communicate recommendations on specific issues to the primary team. The primary team will then implement the plan if in agreement with the recommendations. A consultant may continue to follow a patient if the clinical condition is evolving or when specifically asked to do so, or may sign off when input on the case is complete. In the consultant role, hospitalists do not typically write orders unless specifically asked to do so, but they maintain responsibility to review and interpret results of recommended studies.

A model of shared care known as co-management has evolved between hospitalists and many surgical and other services. There are several styles of co-management, depending on the institution, resources, and specific agreements between services. For example, a hospitalist may serve as the primary clinician with surgeons serving as consultants for a primary surgical problem, or a hospitalist may be an “embedded” consultant within a primary non-hospitalist team. In the latter model, a hospitalist may follow all patients and make recommendations on a broad array of medical issues, as well as write orders and follow up on study results. Co-management is a more collaborative and proactive approach to patient care that promotes clear communication and delineation of responsibilities among services. Although literature has been mixed on clinical outcomes, a retrospective propensity-score analysis found surgical co-management to be associated with decreased complications, reduced inpatient consults, and reduced mortality rates and 30-day readmissions. Surgical co-management has been consistently associated with a high level of satisfaction with the care model among surgeons, nurses, and trainees.

Despite its advantages, co-management also presents challenges. The presence of multiple care providers can result in duplication or omission of care, or care that is in conflict because of unclear division of responsibilities. A diffusion of responsibility may also result in substandard care. Carefully drafted service agreements between participants in the co-management services that outline rules of engagement and division of responsibility are critical for the success of co-management programs.

Hospitalized patients are at risk for many medical complications, several of which can be mitigated through strategies aimed at prevention. Hospitalists are uniquely positioned to reduce inpatient complications. Risk reduction strategies that are commonly initiated include venous thromboembolism (VTE) prophylaxis, delirium prevention and screening, antibiotic stewardship, discontinuation of catheters to prevent catheter-associated infections, prevention of aspiration, interventions to reduce deconditioning and falls, bedsore-prevention initiatives, and medication reconciliation.

VTE risk is elevated in hospitalized, immobile, and acutely ill patients. More than 50% of VTE events occur during or after hospitalization for acute illness or recent surgery. VTE risk is particularly high in ICU patients and patients with cancer or stroke. Early ambulation, mechanical prophylaxis (such as intermittent pneumatic compression devices applied to the lower extremities), and prophylactic anticoagulants are used either alone or in combination to prevent VTE in these patients. Guidance on VTE prevention strategies is provided by the American Society of Hematology and American College of Chest Physicians. A patient's thrombotic risk can be determined by using a validated risk assessment model, such as the Padua Prediction Score

. If bleeding risk is not elevated and VTE risk is high (Padua Score ≥4), use of pharmacologic prophylaxis with daily low-molecular-weight heparin is recommended throughout the patient's hospital stay or until mobility is fully recovered. In patients with an unacceptably high bleeding risk, mechanical prophylaxis with intermittent pneumatic compression may be used, although data supporting this approach in non-surgical patients is limited. . Patients at highest risk include those with advanced age, polypharmacy, prior cognitive impairment, recent surgery, and acute illness. Predisposing and provoking risk factors for delirium are listed in

. Up to 40% of cases of delirium in hospitalized patients can be prevented. Preventive strategies include the use of assistive visual and hearing devices, optimization of pain control, minimization of psychoactive medications, frequent reorientation, early mobilization, and allowance of uninterrupted sleep to promote a normal sleep-wake cycle. Early detection of delirium is of equal importance for prevention of additional complications. The Confusion Assessment Method is an evidence-based screening tool that should be used regularly in high-risk patients.
Hospitalists play a key role in preventing hospital-acquired infections by championing early removal of urinary and central venous catheters and judicious use of antibiotics

Antibiotic stewardship activity in collaboration with infectious disease specialists and pharmacists targets appropriate and timely antibiotic use to prevent antibiotic resistance and decrease the likelihood of complications of antibiotic therapy, including

). Aspiration and resultant respiratory distress can be a devastating pulmonary complication in hospitalized patients, leading to pneumonitis and/or pneumonia. Patients at higher risk for aspiration include those with dysphagia (for example, recent stroke or neuromuscular disease), bowel obstruction or ileus, dementia, delirium, or progressive somnolence. Aspiration prevention strategies include elevation of the head of the bed, swallow evaluation by a speech therapist, assisted feeding, and avoidance of nasogastric tubes.

Several fall prevention strategies can be used in the hospital setting. These strategies include physical and occupational therapy, bed alarms, limitation of medications that cause postural hypotension or weakness, and hospital sitter services for patients with cognitive impairment.
